title: Lamp, "Moss", 1999
provenance: ca. 2000: purchased by Marlene Meyerson (Moss Gallery, New York, NY); 2010: acquired by the Museum
dimensions: H x diam.: 45.7 x 38.1 cm (18 x 15 in.)
description: Malleable globular form with short base, the whole composed of milky-toned silicone string-like trailings; mounted on internal red plastic base housing light bulb and cord.
justification:
From Acquisition Justification:
"Notable Italian architect/designer Gaetano Pesce has been designing furniture and other objects since the 1960s. A number of his works are considered icons of twentieth-century design, and he is particularly noted for his experimental forms in resin and other synthetics that emphasize the creative process in fabricating functional forms in modern materials. 
This "Moss" lamp exemplifies Pesce's approach to "industrialized non-conformity," production using&nbsp; modern fabrication techniques associated with mass-production, comibined with contemporary materials, to produce unique objects. Here the supple silicone is poured and trailed to achieve a basic sphere, but it is not a perfect form. The end result is dictated by the behavior of the material. The form encloses a single incandescent light source that casts a soft glow through the interstices and varied thicknesses of the translucent thread-like trailings of the silicone body. The textured surface also invites the user to touch, its surprisingly warm, soft, and malleable form evoking an emotional response.
This was a prototype. Whether ultimately unique or made as a limited production, the lamp appears as an image in "1999" on the designer's website timeline."

tombstone.epitaph: Lamp, "Moss", 1999.Silicone, plastic, metal. Gift of Marlene Meyerson. 2010-11-1.
